title: Airbnb, Uranium Energy, Biogen: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today; Airbnb shares slipped 1.6% premarket after analysts at Goldman Sachs recommended investors sell the stock
text:
* Uranium Energy, a Texas-based miner and explorer, jumped 7.8%. Shares of uranium miners are surging as retail traders from Reddit's Wall Street Bets forum focus their energies on the rallying radioactive metal.

* Biogen shares rose 1% ahead of the bell. The pharma stock dropped last week after the company said the launch of its Alzheimer's drug, Aduhelm, "was slower than we initially anticipated."

* Invitation Homes gained 3.2% premarket. The single-family-home leasing company said early this month it recently received a letter from the Federal Trade Commission requesting information about how the company conducts its business generally and specifically during the Covid-19 pandemic.

* AMC Entertainment, a favorite of Reddit-active individual traders, rose 3.2%. Meme stocks are distorting the way some investors see parts of the market.

* Global Payments fell 2.1% premarket. Analysts at Morgan Stanley lowered their price target for the payment-technology firm from $219 to $185 a share Friday.

* ViacomCBS shares rose 0.7%. The media company is revamping the operations of its Paramount Pictures movie and television production unit as part of a broader shake-up of the management, The Wall Street Journal reported.

* APA Corp., the holding company for oil-and-gas company Apache, rose 1.7% in premarket trading. Crude-oil prices were heading higher ahead of closely watched supply-and-demand forecasts from OPEC.

* Best Buy rose 0.6% ahead of the bell. The retailer, along with Amazon.com, last week set out a new lineup of smart televisions.

* Wayfair added 1.1%. Shares of the home-goods retailer have fallen over the past month and both Citigroup and Credit Suisse cut their target for the stock in August.

* Unum Group, a Tennessee-based insurer, ticked up 0.7%. S&P Dow Jones Indices said earlier this month Unum would fallout of the S&P 500 and into the S&P MidCap 400 index.

Chart of the Day

After a record-breaking bull run for the U.S. stock market this year, many Wall Street analysts are starting to warn that investors could be in for a bumpy ride.

Write to Joe Wallace at joe.wallace@wsj.com
